title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: McKinsey Must Face Conflict Claims; Aeroméxico Creditors Feel Left Out; Boeing Supplier Protests Exit Plan
text:
McKinsey foe's conflict lawsuit revived. A federal appeals court revived longtime McKinsey & Co. critic Jay Alix's lawsuit alleging the consulting giant concealed disqualifying conflicts of interest to skew the market for bankruptcy advisory work. The ruling by the Second Circuit Court of Appeals in New York revived a racketeering lawsuit accusing McKinsey of submitting false and misleading statements in 13 bankruptcy cases to hide financial conflicts. Mr. Alix has also alleged that McKinsey carried out a pay-to-play scheme in which the firm arranged meetings between its clients and bankruptcy attorneys in exchange for business referrals.

Aeroméxico creditors hit rough air as bankruptcy nears end. Grupo Aeroméxico SA B de CV is close to clinching court approval for a proposed corporate reorganization about 18 months after filing for chapter 11, although some creditors argue the bankruptcy plan unfairly enriches certain shareholders and shouldn't be confirmed. Objecting creditors said in court papers Tuesday they weren't offered the same opportunity to subscribe to a planned sale of Aeroméxico equity as others with equal standing under bankruptcy law.

Owner of bankrupt 737 MAX supplier Tect challenges Boeing's liability release. The owner of bankrupt Tect Aerospace Group Holdings Inc. said it plans to vote against the 737 MAX supplier's chapter 11 liquidation plan if Boeing Co. would receive broad legal protection against liability stemming from the suspension of the jetliner's production.

Bankruptcy

Bankruptcy judge reconstitutes J&J talc cancer committee. A New Jersey bankruptcy judge agreed Wednesday to consolidate two committees representing consumers who allege Johnson & Johnson talcum-based products caused their cancer.

Judge Michael Kaplan of the U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Trenton, N.J. granted a bankrupt J&J subsidiary's request to reconstitute the original claimants' committee formed when it first filed chapter 11 last year in Charlotte, N.C.

After the bankruptcy case was shipped to North Carolina, the Justice Department's bankruptcy watchdog formed two separate committees, one representing consumers with ovarian cancer and the other representing those with mesothelioma. The J&J subsidiary, LTL Management LLC, said there was no legal or practical basis for forming two committees based on disease type and that keeping both committees would incur unnecessary administrative costs. The company has defeated some lawsuits, lost others and maintained that its baby powder is safe. — Jonathan Randles

Luxury retailer Escada America seeks bankruptcy protection. Women's luxury fashion retailer Escada America LLC filed for chapter 11 with the U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Los Angeles after the Covid-19 pandemic devastated the company's brick-and-mortar business, forcing the chapter 11 filing.

Escada America, which operates in the U.S. under a license agreement with global fashion brand Escada, has offices in Beverly Hills, Calif., and New York City, and runs about 10 retail stores across seven states, according to court papers. To stay afloat, the company has negotiated rent workouts with some of its landlords. With the government's eviction moratorium coming to an end, the retailer is seeking bankruptcy protection to restructure, according to court papers. — Akiko Matsuda

People

Lazard restructuring pro Silverman joins baird. Investment bank Lazard Frères's restructuring professional Eli Silverman joined Baird in its newly-created restructuring advisory group. Mr. Silverman was a senior member of the Lazard team advising Pacific Gas and Electric Co. in its chapter 11 case to shield the power company from tens of billions of dollars in potential liabilities related to a 2018 California wildfire that claimed dozens of lives.

He also advised Toys "R" Us's $5 billion debt restructuring. Mr. Silverman earlier worked at private equity firm Z Capital Partners and Blackstone Inc. focusing on corporate turnaround. He joined Baird as a director as the investment bank looks to expand its capacity in advising troubled companies. The middle-market bank started its restructuring group late last year. — Jodi Xu Klein

International

Turkey takes $5 billion lifeline from old rival U.A.E. The United Arab Emirates and Turkey agreed to a currency swap equivalent to nearly $5 billion that reinforces an economic partnership between two Middle Eastern rivals and provides Ankara with a badly needed infusion of foreign funds. The injection of Emirati funds will help Turkey's central bank as it burns through foreign currency reserves to prop up the lira, which lost 40% of its value against the dollar last year. The amount exchanged is modest compared with Turkey's financial needs, however.

In Other News

Lenders to American Physician Partners have given the emergency medical staffing company more time to repay its overdue loans following the collapse of a refinancing deal last month, according to people with knowledge of the matter. (Bloomberg)
